Situation A. +/- Connection

Marta and Evo each wrote an expression to calculate the revenue for the 6th grade.

1. Which expression is correct? Explain why.
  2. Would either of these methods work to write an expression for the revenue for 7th grade? 8th grade?

1. Both expressions are correct. To find the value of an expression you can

  • repeatedly subtract or
  • add everything to be subtracted then do the subtraction all at once.

2. Yes. For 7th grade, Marta’s Expression: 8(50)-29.50-35.25 and Evo’s Expression: 8(50)–(29.50+35.25)

For 8th grade, Marta’s Expression: 7(25)-155.75-30.50 and Evo’s Expression: 7(25)-(155.75+30.50)

Situation B. Anthony, Aretha, and Ricardo’s Conjectures

Examine each claim. Is the claim correct? Explain.

Anthony's Conjecture:

–5 is the opposite of 5. So, the opposite of –5 is – (–5). That is, the subtraction symbol also indicates the opposite of a number.

– (–5) = 5
Anthony is correct. Subtracting a negative number is the same operation as adding a positive number of the same magnitude. So b = -(-b).

Aretha's Conjecture:

Subtraction of rational numbers is not commutative. My example shows why.

5 – 2 ≠ 2 – 5

3 ≠ –3

Aretha is correct that subtraction of rational numbers is not commutative. If you switch the order of the numbers, then your answer will have the opposite sign. The one case where you can switch the order for subtraction without it affecting the final answer is when you are subtracting a number from itself, for example 5 – 5 = 5 – 5.

Ricardo's Conjecture:

I used the chip model to show that 9 – 4 = 9 + (– 4). I can take away 4 black chips or I can add 4 red chips and then take away 4 black chips and 4 red chips. In each case the answer is 5.

Ricardo is correct. Subtraction can be computed by “taking away” or by adding the opposite of the minuend.

p – q = p + (–q)

Situation C. Hank Cards: Relating Addition and Subtraction

Hank added cards to the Algebra Connection Game to develop understanding of the relationship between addition and subtraction of rational numbers.

For each card find a value of n.

• Card 13. n = 10, because 8 – (-2) = 8 + 2 (relationship between addition and subtraction)
  • Card 14. n = 30, because n + 5 = 35 can be rewritten as 35 – 5 = n (fact family)
  • Card 15.n = 40, because n – 5 = 35 can be rewritten as 35 + 5 = n (fact family)
  • Card 16.n = 30, because n – (-5) = 35 can be rewritten as 35 + 5 = n (fact family)
  • Card 17.n = 39, because 4 + n = 43 can be rewritten as 43 – 4 = n (fact family)
  • Card 18.n = 47, because -4 + n = 43 can be rewritten as 43 – (- 4) = n (fact family)
  • Card 19.n = 39, because -4 – n = –43 can be rewritten as -43 + 39 = -4 (fact family)

Note: Some students will compute these equations mentally without needing to use fact families. Their number sense will help them find the value of n.
